GROWTH STUDIES OF DAIRY HEIFERS II 1 PROTEIN REQUIREMENTS FOR GROWING HEIFERS DEPARTMENT OF DAIRY HUSBANDRY" Proper growth ami development depends upon a satisfac - tory ration. Such a ration must contain the right balance be - tween the various nutrients. Because it is so intimately con - nected with the body development, protein is perhaps the most important >injrle nutrient for growing animals. Protein, there - fore, nay be and frequently is the limiting factor in successful grow tli of ilairv cattle. If any portion of the feed may be said to play a dual role, it is the protein. The nitrogenous part of the ration serves a necessary function in providing for growth of body parts and further may !>e ued a> a source of energy for the carrying on i.f UhIv functions. It mav serve in either wav. but not in both ivs at the Mime time. As a contribution to the subject of pro- is related to the growth of young animals, these data arc t METHODS OF INVESTIGATION For the experiment eight animals were selected, consisting ix purebred Jersey heifers and two purebred Holstein eifers. These were divided into two groups, each of which ontained three Jerseys and a Holstein. In the experiment, \\;i- exercised to pair related animals. In every case the pairs were half sisters and in some in - inces had "■"> per cent of the same ancestral inheritance. The inscription of the animals used in this experiment is given in Fable 1. while the grouping is shown in Table 2. Group 1 in- led Jersey heifers Nos. 1, .'}. and 5 and Holstein heifer Xo. . I hi- group \va> placed on a high protein plane of nutri- tion. Group -! consisted of Jersey heifers Nos. "2. 4. and <> and Holstein heifer No. -J.">r.. and was placed on a much lower al - lowance of protein. The feeding trials were first started on January 1. 1919. with pairs I. II, and III (See Table 1) but con - siderable difficulty was experienced in getting the animals to 'Bulletin 181. "Effect of Light and Heavy Feeding of Wide and Narrow Rations." was the first of this series. This experiment was conducted by W. B. Nevens and J. W. Hendrickson. under the direction of J. H. Frandsen. The data were organized and prepared for publication by H. P. Davis and Benjamin Masurovsky. 'The experiment was carried on under a general plan outlined by H. P. Armsby. late Director of the Institute of Animal Nutrition of the Pennsylvania State College.

Height at hi]>- i> the height from the floor to the top of tli«' hook or hip hone. The width at hips is the extreme dis - tance from the outside of the hook or hip bones. Length of ImhIv i- the distance from the lower front point of the shoulder Uiiic t<> the rear of the pin bone. If the body of the animal Ik 1 considered a- a parallelogram, then the length of the body ooiTMfMads nearly to the diagonal. The measurements and weights of individual animals appear in Table 8. The ImkIv measurements showing skeletal development of the experiment*! animals were computed (see Table 0) as follows: 1. The average monthly gains of body weight ami measure - ments were calculated in the following way. The total gain for the entire experimental period was divided by the number of dare in the period, the quotient multiplied by 30 (average number of day- in month), and the product considered as the average monthly rain. aiwr i otnet protrin «ertjr< I /.(.-. The average monthly gain in height at wither>. height at hips, width at hips, length of body, and heart girth were calculated on the basis of the average monthly gain in live weight. The computation was Imx'd not upon the entire actual gain but upon 100 lbs. of gain in live weight. th Averages of each measurement were computed for the ip> in order to facilitate the comparison of results. Table Si rs in detail the average monthly gains in bodv measure- From the data presented, there appears to be no significant difference between the two groups a> showing that the protein plane had any effect upon skeletal development. It nin-t be renieml>ered. however, that the low protein plane upon which (Jroup II waa fed was above the minimum required by growing heifers. The higher plane upon which Group I wa« fed hail an excess of protein. Tliir- excess does not ap)x-ar to have lia< I any significant effect upon skeletal development. ProbaMv t!i- increased protein ingested l>y Group I did not influence the mineral metabolism to any appreciable degree as determined by lxxlv measurement-. Growth Sti dikk <>f Dairy Hkikkrs 17 EFFECT ON BODY WEIGHT The average monthly gains in body weight wore calculated on the liii~i~ of 1.(mk> 11)-. live weijrlit for each animal of each group. The group averages, then, were taken for comparing re-ult> obtained from high or low protein rations. Examining Table !•. it i> found that Group II on the lower protein intake gained, on the average. (5O.3fi lbs. of bodv weight per month as compared with .">.">.:>."> 11». of gain made by Group I fed on the higher protein ration when figured on the basis of 1,000 lbs. live weight . Table 1 * » points out the average amounts of crude protein consumed to make ;i pound of gain in body weight and the average daily gain in body weight j>er 1.000 lbs. live weight exhibited by the two groups. Group I. receiving the high protein ration, rewired 2. - 2O Hi-, of crude protein per pound gain in body weight, while Group II fed on the low protein ration, consumed 1.17 lbs. of crude protein for each pound of gain in body weight. Fur - thermore, the average daily gain in body weight per 1.000 lbs. live weight was 1.84 ll>s. for Group I. and "2.01 lbs. in the case of Group II. Xkbkaska Kxi-khimkm Statiom Hi i.i.ktin 1M 18 CONCLUSIONS kl. The skeletal development of growing dairy cattle does seem to be influenced bv mi increase in the protein content a ration carrying slightly more protein than the minimum by feeding standards. An excess of protein apparently tends to diminish the rage daily gain or body weight ]>er 1.000 lbs. live weight growing heifers. ;i. A high protein ration i> not economical for growing dairy heifers. l>ecanse there is more crude protein consumed ]xt ]H>und gain in body weight than in the case of a ration computed according to current feeding standard- and there appears to l>c no compensatory l>enefit. BIBLIOGRAPHY 1. T. B. Osborne, L. B. Mendel, and E. L. Ferry. Carnegie Institute, Washington, Pub. 156, (19111 p. 111. Nutrition factors which influence growth. 2. L. B. Mendel Trans. 15 International Cong. Hyg. and Demogra - phy, Washington, 2, (1912) Sect. 2, pp. 429-438. The role of protein in growth. 3. T. S. Osborne and L. B. Mendel. J. Biol.
